poem:
"Depths of Silver"

From the ancient ocean, a bounty raised,
Silver bars, counted, secret, appraised.
Yet not for Marshall, does the treasure linger,
Slipped through fingers, like sea-foam whisper.
A war's lost whisper claimed by silent brine,
Now under South Africa's betraying sunshine.
The law's stern verdict, on currents bestowed,
In the cruel caprice of the ocean's code.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "GB News joint owner loses fight over £34m of secretly salvaged silver The joint owner of GB News has lost a legal battle with the South African government over £34m of silver secretly salvaged from a second world war shipwreck. Sir Paul Marshall, who is lining up a bid for the Daily Telegraph, had claimed ownership of 2,364 silver bars his company had recovered from the bottom of the Indian Ocean. This claim was successfully". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
